questions.text: All of the following arteries are branch of the maxillary artery, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Maxillary Artery:
    • Origin: It is the larger terminal branch of the external carotid artery, arising behind the neck of the mandible.
    • Course: Runs horizontally forward to the lower border of the lateral pterygoid muscle.
    • Division: Divided into three parts based on its relation to the lateral pterygoid muscle, each with distinct branches.
  • Branches of Maxillary Artery:
    • 1st Part (Mandibular Part):
      • Inferior alveolar artery: Supplies the lower teeth and chin.
      • Deep auricular artery: Supplies the external acoustic meatus and tympanic membrane.
      • Anterior tympanic artery: Supplies the tympanic membrane.
      • Middle meningeal artery: Supplies the meninges and the cranial cavity.
      • Accessory meningeal artery: Supplies the meninges and the foramen ovale.
    • 2nd Part (Pterygoid Part):
      • Buccal artery: Supplies the buccinator muscle and the mucosa of the cheek.
      • Deep temporal arteries: Supply the temporalis muscle.
    • 3rd Part (Pterygopalatine Part):
      • Infraorbital artery: Supplies the face below the orbit and branches into several facial arteries.
      • Posterior superior alveolar artery: Supplies the maxillary molars and sinus.
  • Superficial Temporal Artery:
    • Origin: A terminal branch of the external carotid artery, not associated with the maxillary artery.
    • Supplies: The temporal region and branches into the frontal and parietal branches.

Why Not Others?

  • A. Inferior alveolar artery: Correctly a branch of the 1st part of the maxillary artery, supplying the lower jaw.
  • B. Infraorbital artery: Correctly a branch of the 3rd part of the maxillary artery, providing blood supply to the maxilla and face.
  • D. Buccal artery: Correctly a branch of the 2nd part of the maxillary artery, supplying the cheek region.

Key Takeaway:

The superficial temporal artery is not a branch of the maxillary artery; it is a terminal branch of the external carotid artery, confirming that Option C is the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is get inserted to the marked area of mandible in the given figure below?
questions.solution:
• Marked Area: Refers to the rough surface on the medial surface of the angle of the mandible, specifically the area receiving the insertion of the medial pterygoid muscle.
  • Muscles of Mastication:
  • Lateral Pterygoid:
  • Origin:
    • Upper head: Infratemporal surface and crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid.
    • Lower head: Lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate of the sphenoid.
  • Insertion: Pterygoid fovea on the neck of the mandible and the articular disc and capsule of the temporomandibular joint.
  • Medial Pterygoid:
    • Origin:
      • Superficial head: Maxillary tuberosity and lateral surface of the pyramidal process of the palatine bone.
      • Deep head: Medial surface of the lateral pterygoid plate and grooved surface of the pyramidal process of the palatine bone.
    • Insertion: Roughened area on the posteroinferior part of the medial surface and angle of the ramus of the mandible, extending to the mandibular foramen and mylohyoid groove.
  • Temporalis:
    • Origin: Temporal fossa and temporal fascia.
    • Insertion: Medial surface, apex, and anterior border of the coronoid process of the ramus of the mandible.
  • Masseter:
    • Origin:
      • Superficial layer: Maxillary process of the zygomatic bone and anterior two-thirds of the inferior border of the zygomatic arch.
      • Middle layer: Lower border of the posterior one-third of the zygomatic arch.
      • Deep layer: Deep surface of the zygomatic arch.
    • Insertion:
      • Superficial fibers: Angle and lower posterior half of the lateral surface of the ramus of the mandible.
      • Middle fibers: Central part of the ramus.
      • Deep fibers: Upper part of the mandibular ramus and coronoid process.

Why Not Others?

  • A. Lateral Pterygoid: Inserts into the pterygoid fovea on the mandible, not the marked area.
  • C. Temporalis: Inserts onto the coronoid process, not the medial surface of the angle of the mandible.
  • D. Masseter: Inserts primarily on the lateral surface of the ramus, not the medial area.

Key Takeaway:

The medial pterygoid muscle is responsible for the insertion at the rough surface on the medial angle of the mandible, confirming that Option B is the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of mandibular nerve?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Buccal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve providing sensory innervation to the cheek area.
  • Option B: Auriculotemporal Nerve: A sensory branch of the mandibular nerve supplying the skin of the anterior ear and temporal region.
  • Option C: Deep Temporal Nerve: A branch of the mandibular nerve that innervates the temporalis muscle.
  • Option D: Zygomatic Nerve:
    • Incorrect: It is a branch of the maxillary nerve, not the mandibular nerve.

Branches of the Mandibular Nerve:

  • From the Main Trunk:
    • Meningeal branch (to dura mater of the middle cranial fossa)
    • Nerve to the medial pterygoid
  • From the Anterior Trunk:
    • Buccal nerve
    • Masseteric nerve
    • Deep temporal nerves
    • Nerve to the lateral pterygoid
  • From the Posterior Trunk:
    • Auriculotemporal nerve
    • Lingual nerve
    • Inferior alveolar nerve

Branches of the Maxillary Nerve:

  • In the Middle Cranial Fossa: Meningeal branch (to dura mater)
  • In the Pterygopalatine Fossa:
    • Posterior superior alveolar nerve
    • Zygomatic Nerve (incorrect option)
  • In the Infratemporal Fossa:
    • Middle superior alveolar nerve
    • Anterior superior alveolar nerve

Key Takeaway:

The zygomatic nerve is a branch of the maxillary nerve, confirming that Option D is not a branch of the mandibular nerve.

questions.text: All of the following muscles help in elevation of temporo-mandibular joint, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Muscles and Movements of the TM Joint:

  • Depression:
    • Lateral Pterygoid (main muscle).
    • Assists from Digastric, Geniohyoid, and Mylohyoid during wide mouth opening.
  • Elevation:
    • Masseter: Main muscle for elevation.
    • Temporalis: Anterior and middle fibers elevate the mandible.
    • Medial Pterygoid: Complements other muscles in elevation.
  • Protrusion:
    • Lateral Pterygoid and Medial Pterygoid: Key for moving the jaw forward.
  • Retraction:
    • Involves posterior fibers of Temporalis and deep fibers of Masseter.
  • Side-to-side Movements:
    • Involves coordinated action between the lateral and medial pterygoids, allowing for effective grinding during chewing.

Key Points:

Why Not Others:

  • Option A: Medial Pterygoid
    • Role: Contributes to elevation, working synergistically with masseter and temporalis for effective chewing.
  • Option C: Masseter
    • Role: A major elevator of the mandible, essential for strong biting and grinding of food.
  • Option D: Temporalis
    • Role: Elevates the mandible, particularly with its anterior fibers, which also help retract the jaw for precision in chewing.

Key Takeaway:

The lateral pterygoid muscle is not involved in elevating the TM joint, making Option B the correct answer. The other muscles play essential roles in the elevation and overall movement of the mandible, crucial for functions like chewing and speaking.

questions.text: Injury to pterygopalatine ganglion leads to loss of secretomotor connections to which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
• Pterygopalatine Ganglion (PG):
    • Functions: It is the largest parasympathetic ganglion and acts as a relay station for secretomotor fibers.
    • Connections:
      • Lacrimal gland (Option A): Directly receives its secretomotor fibers via the pterygopalatine ganglion.
      • Mucous glands of the nose, palate, pharynx, and paranasal sinuses are also innervated by fibers from the PG.
    • Location: Situated in the pterygopalatine fossa, connected to the maxillary nerve and functionally linked to the facial nerve through the greater petrosal nerve.
  • Other Options:
    • Parotid gland (Option B): Innervated by the otic ganglion; hence, injury to the PG does not affect it.
    • Submandibular gland (Option C): Innervated by the submandibular ganglion, thus unaffected by PG injury.
    • Sublingual gland (Option D): Also supplied by the submandibular ganglion, making it independent of the PG.

Why Not Others:

  • Option B: Parotid Gland
    • Innervation: Supplied by the otic ganglion, independent of the pterygopalatine ganglion.
  • Option C: Submandibular Gland
    • Innervation: Connected to the submandibular ganglion, not influenced by pterygopalatine injury.
  • Option D: Sublingual Gland
    • Innervation: Receives fibers from the submandibular ganglion, unaffected by PG damage.

Key Takeaways:

Injury to the pterygopalatine ganglion primarily affects the lacrimal gland (Option A) due to its direct secretomotor connections. The other options are linked to different ganglia, thus remaining unaffected by such an injury. Understanding the specific roles and connections of cranial ganglia is crucial for grasping their clinical implications.

questions.text: 60 years old male patient came to OPD with the complaint of the loss of sensation on anterior part of tongue. On examination doctor found that patient had normal taste sensation with loss of general sensations. Which of the following nerve is damaged in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue but intact taste sensation.
  • The lingual nerve (branch of the mandibular nerve, CN V3) is responsible for general sensation of this region, while taste sensation is supplied by the chorda tympani nerve (branch of the facial nerve, CN VII). Damage to the lingual nerve results in loss of general sensation while preserving taste.

Sensory supply of tongue:


Why Not Others:

  • A (Chorda tympani nerve): Affects taste, not general sensation.
  • C (Glossopharyngeal nerve): Supplies general and taste sensation to the posterior third of the tongue.
  • D (Hypoglossal nerve): Controls motor function of the tongue, not sensation.

Key Takeaways:

  • The lingual nerve is responsible for general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, while taste sensation is carried by the chorda tympani nerve.

questions.text: All of the following structures are forming the tonsillar bed, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The tonsillar bed (or lateral wall of the tonsillar fossa) is primarily composed of the pharyngobasilar fascia, palatopharyngeus muscle, superior constrictor muscle, and buccopharyngeal fascia.
  • Thyropharyngeus muscle (part of the inferior constrictor) does not contribute to the formation of the tonsillar bed.
  • The bed of the tonsil is formed from within outwards by:
    • The pharyngobasilar fascia
    • The superior constrictor and palatopharyngeus muscles
    • The buccopharyngeal fascia
    • In the lower part, the styloglossus
    • The glossopharyngeal nerve

Why Not Others:

  • A (Palatopharyngeus muscle): Forms part of the posterior boundary and contributes to the lateral wall.
  • B (Pharyngobasilar fascia): Part of the lateral wall of the tonsillar bed.
  • C (Buccopharyngeal fascia): Also part of lateral wall

Key Takeaways:

  • The tonsillar bed is mainly formed by pharyngobasilar fascia, superior constrictor muscle, and associated structures, while the thyropharyngeus muscle plays no role in this formation.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not arising from palatine aponeurosis?
questions.solution:
• Levator veli palati does not arise from the palatine aponeurosis; it inserts onto the aponeurosis after originating from the cartilaginous part of the auditory tube and petrous temporal bone.
  • The other muscles (Musculus uvulae, Palatoglossus, and Palatopharyngeus) arise from the palatine aponeurosis.
  • Muscles attached to palatine aponeurosis:
    • Origin of Musculus uvulae, Palato-glossus and Palato-pharayngeus
    • Insertion of Tensor veli palati and Levator veli palati
    • All the muscles of soft palate are supplied by the cranial root of accessory nerve via pharyngeal plexus except tensor palati, which is supplied by the nerve to medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Musculus uvulae): Arises from the palatine aponeurosis.
  • C (Palatoglossus): Arises from the palatine aponeurosis.
  • D (Palatopharyngeus): Arises from the palatine aponeurosis.

Key Takeaways:

  • The palatine aponeurosis serves as the origin for several soft palate muscles, but the Levator veli palati only inserts there, originating from the auditory tube and petrous bone.
  • All the muscles of soft palate are supplied by the cranial root of accessory nerve via pharyngeal plexus except tensor palati, which is supplied by the nerve to medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve.

choices.text: It lies opposite to C3, C4, C5, C6 vertebrae
It is only endocrine gland located superficially
It regulates the basal metabolic rate

questions.text: Which of following is incorrect about the thyroid gland?
questions.solution:
• Vertebral level: The thyroid gland lies opposite C5, C6, C7, and T1 vertebrae, not C3-C6 as stated in option B.
  • Size: It is the largest endocrine gland in the body (Option A).
  • Location: It is the only endocrine gland located superficially, easily accessible for clinical examination (Option C).
  • Function: The thyroid gland regulates basal metabolic rate through the release of hormones T3 and T4, influencing metabolic activities, growth, and development (Option D).
  • Hormones: The gland secretes triiodothyronine (T3), thyroxine (T4), and calcitonin, which play roles in metabolism and calcium regulation.
  • Storage: Unlike other endocrine glands, the thyroid stores its hormones in follicles before releasing them into the bloodstream as needed.
  • Iodine: It is the only endocrine gland that depends on iodine from the external environment for hormone synthesis.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Correct, the thyroid is the largest endocrine gland.
  • C: Correct, it is the only superficially located endocrine gland.
  • D: Correct, thyroid hormones regulate the basal metabolic rate.

Key Takeaways:

  • The thyroid gland lies opposite C5-T1 vertebrae, is the largest endocrine gland, regulates the basal metabolic rate, stores its hormones in follicles, and requires iodine for hormone synthesis.

questions.text: Kocher's vein of thyroid gland drains into?
questions.solution:
• Kocher's vein is an important anatomical structure of the thyroid gland that drains directly into the internal jugular vein.
  • The thyroid gland is highly vascularized, requiring efficient venous drainage, which is facilitated by several key veins:
  • Superior thyroid vein: Arises from the upper pole of the thyroid lobe, runs upwards and laterally, and drains into the internal jugular vein. This vein provides drainage for the upper part of the gland.
  • Middle thyroid vein: Originates from the middle of the thyroid lobe and also drains directly into the internal jugular vein, contributing to the central drainage of the gland.
  • Inferior thyroid veins: Emerge from the lower part of the thyroid gland, forming a plexus around the trachea, and drain into the left brachiocephalic vein. This vein primarily manages the lower drainage of the gland.
  • The venous anatomy of the thyroid gland allows for efficient drainage of metabolic waste and hormonal secretions directly into the systemic circulation.

Why Not Others:

  • External jugular vein: Primarily drains superficial neck structures, such as the scalp and face, and does not collect blood from the thyroid gland.
  • Right brachiocephalic vein: Although it receives blood from multiple veins, it does not have a direct connection to the thyroid venous drainage system.
  • Left brachiocephalic vein: While it does receive drainage from the inferior thyroid veins, it does not accommodate Kocher's vein.

Key Takeaway:
Kocher's vein drains into the internal jugular vein, a crucial pathway in the thyroid's venous drainage system. This system ensures efficient removal of blood from the gland, along with the superior and middle thyroid veins.

choices.text: The superior thyroid artery to be ligated away from the apex of gland and the inferior thyroid artery to be ligated near to base of the gland
The superior thyroid artery to be ligated near the apex of gland and the inferior thyroid artery to be ligated away from base of the gland
Both the arteries to be ligated as possible as near to the gland
Both the arteries to be ligated as possible as away from the gland

questions.text: 60 years old female diagnosed with the goiter. He was undergone with thyroidectomy. Which of the following care to be taken during surgery?
questions.solution:
• Thyroidectomy involves the surgical removal of the thyroid gland and requires careful management of the associated blood vessels to prevent complications.
  • Ligation of thyroid arteries is crucial for protecting surrounding nerves:
    • Superior thyroid artery:
      • Lies superficially near the apex of the thyroid lobe.
      • The external laryngeal nerve runs deep to the apex.
      • Ligation should be done close to the apex to avoid injury to the external laryngeal nerve, preserving laryngeal function.
    • Inferior thyroid artery:
      • The recurrent laryngeal nerve runs closely to the base of the thyroid lobe.
      • To minimize the risk of nerve damage, the inferior thyroid artery should be ligated away from the base of the gland.
  • During thyroidectomy, the superior thyroid artery should be ligated as close to the apex of thyroid lobe as possible to avoid injury to the external laryngeal nerve.
  • During thyroidectomy, the inferior thyroid artery should be ligated as away from the base of the thyroid lobe as possible to avoid injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Ligation of the superior thyroid artery away from the apex increases the risk of nerve injury.
  • C: Ligation as close as possible to both arteries can lead to nerve damage, especially the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
  • D: Ligation away from the gland for both arteries does not provide the necessary protection for surrounding nerves.

Key Takeaway:
During thyroidectomy, ligating the superior thyroid artery near the apex and the inferior thyroid artery away from the base is essential to avoid nerve injuries, particularly to the external laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the subclavian artery?
questions.solution:
• The subclavian artery has specific branches that supply various regions:
    • Vertebral artery: Supplies blood to the brain and spinal cord.
    • Internal thoracic artery: Supplies the anterior chest wall and the breasts.
    • Thyrocervical trunk: Gives rise to several arteries, including:
      • Inferior thyroid artery
      • Suprascapular artery
      • Transverse cervical artery
    • Costocervical trunk: Supplies the upper intercostal spaces and deep neck muscles.
    • Dorsal scapular artery: Supplies the muscles of the back.
  • The superior thyroid artery is not a branch of the subclavian artery; it branches off the external carotid artery.
  • Branches of subclavian artery:
  • Vertebral artery
  • Internal thoracic artery
  • Thyrocervical trunk
  • Costocervical trunk
  • Dorsal scapular artery

Why Not Others:

  • Dorsal scapular artery: Branches from the subclavian artery.
  • Suprascapular artery: Also branches from the subclavian artery.
  • Vertebral artery: Direct branch of the subclavian artery.

Key Takeaway:

The superior thyroid artery is not a branch of the subclavian artery; it originates from the external carotid artery, while the other options are direct branches of the subclavian artery.

questions.text: Which of the following vein is draining into the left brachiocephalic vein but not into the right brachiocephalic vein?
questions.solution:
• The superior intercostal vein:
    • Drains the upper intercostal spaces (2nd to 4th) on the left side into the left brachiocephalic vein.
    • On the right side, it drains into the azygos vein, which then connects to the superior vena cava.
    • This difference in drainage is significant for anatomical and clinical considerations, especially in procedures involving the chest.
  • Other options:
    • Vertebral vein:
      • Drains blood from the cervical spine and structures, entering both the right and left brachiocephalic veins.
    • Inferior thyroid vein:
      • Drains the thyroid gland and typically enters both brachiocephalic veins, providing essential venous drainage for the thyroid.
    • 1st posterior intercostal vein:
      • Drains the first intercostal space and also enters both the right and left brachiocephalic veins.
  • The anatomy of the brachiocephalic veins is critical in various medical procedures, including central venous catheterization and understanding collateral circulation in cases of obstruction.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Vertebral vein): Present on both sides, draining into both brachiocephalic veins.
  • B (Inferior thyroid vein): Drains into both right and left brachiocephalic veins.
  • C (1st posterior intercostal vein): Also drains into both brachiocephalic veins.

Key Takeaway:

The superior intercostal vein uniquely drains into the left brachiocephalic vein but not into the right, highlighting the anatomical differences in venous drainage in the thoracic region.

questions.text: Which of the following paranasal sinus opens into the superior meatus?
questions.solution:
• The superior meatus is a narrow passage in the nasal cavity located below the superior nasal concha.
    • It primarily serves as the drainage pathway for the posterior ethmoidal sinuses, allowing mucous to exit into the nasal cavity.
  • Other sinus openings:
    • Frontal sinus: Drains into the middle meatus through the frontonasal duct.
    • Anterior ethmoidal sinus: Opens into the middle meatus as well.
    • Middle ethmoidal sinus: Also drains into the middle meatus.
  • The anatomy of the nasal cavity is crucial for understanding sinusitis and other nasal pathologies, as blockage in these openings can lead to complications.
  • Openings into middle meatus:
    • Opening of the middle ethmoidal air sinuses
    • Opening of the frontal air sinus
    • Opening of the anterior ethmoidal air sinuses
    • Opening of the maxillary air sinus

Why Not Others:

  • A (Frontal sinus): Drains into the middle meatus.
  • B (Anterior ethmoidal sinus): Opens into the middle meatus.
  • C (Middle ethmoidal sinus): Also drains into the middle meatus.

Key Takeaway:

The posterior ethmoidal sinus uniquely opens into the superior meatus, differentiating it from the frontal, anterior, and middle ethmoidal sinuses, which all drain into the middle meatus.

questions.text: 5 years old male child brought to emergency department with C/O of bleeding from nose. On examination doctor diagnosed that there is trauma over the little's area. Which of the following artery does not take part in the formation of vascular plexus at affected area?
questions.solution:
• Little's area (Kiesselbach's plexus) is a highly vascular region in the anterior part of the nasal septum where several arteries anastomose, making it a common site for epistaxis (nosebleeds).
  • Arteries contributing to Kiesselbach's plexus:
    • Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery: Contributes to the plexus.
    • Septal branch of the sphenopalatine artery: Contributes to the plexus.
    • Septal branch of the greater palatine artery: Contributes to the plexus.
    • Superior labial artery: Contributes to the plexus.
  • Posterior ethmoidal artery: D
    • Does not participate in forming Kiesselbach's plexus and is not involved in the vascular supply to this area, making it the correct answer.

Why Not Others:

  • B (Greater palatine artery): Contributes to the plexus.
  • C (Superior labial artery): Contributes to the plexus.
  • A (Sphenopalatine artery): Contributes to the plexus.

Key Takeaway:

The posterior ethmoidal artery is not involved in the formation of Kiesselbach's plexus at Little's area, while the anterior ethmoidal, sphenopalatine, greater palatine, and superior labial arteries contribute to this vascular plexus, which is critical in managing epistaxis.

questions.text: 60 years old male patient came to OPD with C/O loss of sensation on the marked area in the figure below. Which of the following nerve is affected in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The marked area refers to the concha of the ear, a large depression leading to the external auditory meatus.
  • The sensory supply of the external ear is as follows:
    • Lateral surface:
      • Lower one-third: Greater auricular nerve (Option A).
      • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (Option B), a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve.
      • Concha: Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also known as Alderman's nerve) (Option C), which supplies sensory innervation to this area.
  • Medial surface:
    • Lower one-third: Greater auricular nerve.
    • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2).
    • Eminentia conchae: Auricular branch of the vagus nerve.
  • The motor supply to the external ear is provided by the facial nerve, which innervates the muscles of the auricle.

Why Not Others:

  • A (Greater auricular nerve): Supplies the lower one-third of the lateral surface, not the concha.
  • B (Auriculotemporal nerve): Supplies the upper two-thirds of the lateral surface, not the concha.
  • D (Auricular branch of the facial nerve): Supplies the muscles of the auricle, not sensory innervation.

Key Takeaway:

The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Alderman's nerve) is responsible for sensory innervation to the concha of the ear, making it the affected nerve in this patient with loss of sensation in that area.

questions.text: 50 years old male patient came to ENT OPD with C/O pain and discharge from ear. Doctor examined the tympanic membrane by pulling pinna. In which direction does the doctor had pulled pinna?
questions.solution:
• To examine the tympanic membrane, the pinna must be pulled upwards, backwards, and laterally (Option B). This alignment allows for a better view of the tympanic membrane.

External Auditory Meatus:

  • Also known as the external acoustic meatus, it extends from the concha to the tympanic membrane, measuring about 24 mm in length.
  • Parts:
    • Cartilaginous part (outer one-third):
      • Approximately 8 mm long.
      • Contains hair and ceruminous glands, which produce earwax.
    • Bony part (inner two-thirds):
      • Approximately 16 mm long.
      • Skin is thin, continuous with the tympanic membrane's cuticular layer, and lacks hair and ceruminous glands.
  • Shape:
    • The external auditory meatus is not a straight tube; it has an S-shaped course:
      • Outer part: Directed upwards, backwards, and medially (UBM).
      • Inner part: Directed downwards, forwards, and medially (DFM).
  • Pulling the pinna in the specified direction helps to align these parts, facilitating a clear examination.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Downward, backward, and laterally:
    • This direction would not properly align the meatus for examination, making it difficult to visualize the tympanic membrane effectively.
  • C. Downward, backward, and medially:
    • This position does not correspond with the required orientation for a clear view of the tympanic membrane; it could obscure it instead.
  • D. Upward, backward, and medially:
    • Pulling medially does not provide the necessary lateral alignment, which is crucial for a clear view of the tympanic membrane.

Key Takeaway: The pinna should be pulled upwards, backwards, and laterally to properly visualize the tympanic membrane, making Option B the correct answer.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscle fibres are form the superior constrictor of the pharynx?
I. Thyropharyngeus
II. Glossopharyngeus
III. Cricopharyngeus
IV. Mylopharyngeus
questions.solution:
• The superior constrictor of the pharynx is formed by:
    • Glossopharyngeus (II): Arises from the side of the posterior part of the tongue, contributing to the superior constrictor.
    • Mylopharyngeus (IV): Originates from the medial surface of the mandible, near the mylohyoid line.
  • The thyropharyngeus (I) and cricopharyngeus (III) contribute to the inferior constrictor, hence they are not part of the superior constrictor.

Muscles of the Pharynx:

  • Constrictors of Pharynx:
    • The muscular wall is formed by three pairs: superior, middle, and inferior.
    • Superior Constrictor Origins:
      • Pterygoid hamulus (pterygopharyngeus).
      • Pterygomandibular raphe (buccopharyngeus).
      • Medial surface of the mandible (mylopharyngeus).
      • Side of posterior part of the tongue (glossopharyngeus).
  • Middle Constrictor Origins:
    • Lower part of the stylohyoid ligament.
    • Lesser cornua of hyoid bone.
    • Upper border of the greater cornua of the hyoid bone.
  • Inferior Constrictor:
    • Thyropharyngeus: Arises from the thyroid cartilage.
    • Cricopharyngeus: Arises from the cricoid cartilage.
  • Longitudinal Muscles:
    • Stylopharyngeus: Arises from the styloid process.
    • Palatopharyngeus: Descends from the sides of the palate.
    • Salpingopharyngeus: Merges with palatopharyngeus from the auditory tube.

Why Not Others:

  • A. I & II:
    • Includes thyropharyngeus, which is part of the inferior constrictor and not relevant here.
  • B. III & IV:
    • Includes cricopharyngeus, which is also part of the inferior constrictor, thus incorrect.
  • C. I & III:
    • Both options are components of the inferior constrictor, making this combination incorrect.

Key Takeaway: The superior constrictor comprises the glossopharyngeus and mylopharyngeus (Option D), which are essential for pharyngeal contraction during swallowing.

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels
Recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels
Recurrent laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels

questions.text: 40 years old male patient diagnosed with the narrowing of the tracheooesophageal groove present between the inferior constricor and oesophagus. Which of the following structure is likely to be affected in the patient?
questions.solution:
• The tracheoesophageal groove is located between the inferior constrictor muscle and the esophagus.
  • This groove contains the recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels, which can be affected in the presence of narrowing.

Gaps in the Pharyngeal Wall:

  • Between the base of skull and superior constrictor (sinus of Morgagni):
    • Auditory tube
    • Levator palati muscle
    • Ascending palatine artery
    • Palatine branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Between the superior and middle constrictors:
    • Stylopharyngeus muscle
    • Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Between the middle and inferior constrictors:
    • Internal laryngeal nerve
    • Superior laryngeal vessels
  • Between the lower border of inferior constrictor and esophagus (tracheoesophageal groove):
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve
    • Inferior laryngeal vessels

Why Not Others:

  • A. Internal laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels:
    • The internal laryngeal nerve passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not in the tracheoesophageal groove.
  • C. Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels:
    • The internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels are also located between the middle and inferior constrictors.
  • D. Recurrent laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal vessels:
    • While the recurrent laryngeal nerve is in the groove, the superior laryngeal vessels do not pass through this area.

Key Takeaway: In the tracheoesophageal groove, the affected structures include the recurrent laryngeal nerve and inferior laryngeal vessels (Option B), making them critical for maintaining laryngeal function.

questions.text: Which of the following pair of the muscles provide intorsion movement of eyeball?
questions.solution:
• The intorsion movement of the eyeball is primarily produced by:
    • Superior rectus
    • Inferior oblique muscles.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Superior rectus and superior oblique:
    • The superior oblique muscle primarily facilitates depression and abduction, not intorsion.
  • C. Inferior rectus and inferior oblique:
    • This combination results in extorsion, which is the opposite of intorsion.
  • D. Inferior rectus and superior oblique:
    • The inferior rectus assists with extorsion, while the superior oblique aids in depression and abduction.

Key Takeaway: The superior rectus and inferior oblique are essential for the intorsion movement of the eyeball (Option A), crucial for maintaining visual alignment and stability during head movements.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is affected in case of injury to trochlear nerve?
questions.solution:
• The trochlear nerve (IV) specifically innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • Injury to this nerve results in dysfunction of the superior oblique muscle.
  • (SO4)superior oblique -4th nerve trochlear
  • (LR6)lateral rectus -6th nerve abducens nerve

Nerve Supply of Extraocular Muscles:

Why Not Others:

  • A. Superior rectus:
    • Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, not affected by trochlear nerve injury.
  • B. Inferior rectus:
    • Also innervated by the oculomotor nerve; thus, not impacted by trochlear nerve injury.
  • D. Inferior oblique:
    • Supplied by the oculomotor nerve and unaffected by trochlear nerve damage.

Key Takeaway: Injury to the trochlear nerve primarily affects the superior oblique muscle (Option C), leading to difficulty in intorsion and depression of the eyeball, resulting in characteristic symptoms such as diplopia.

questions.text: All of the following muscles producing the adduction movement of vocal cord, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• The posterior cricoarytenoid muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, responsible for opening the rima glottidis to allow airflow during breathing.
  • All other listed muscles are involved in adduction of the vocal cords.

Movement of Vocal Cords:

Safety muscles of the larynx:

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the only intrinsic muscles that abduct the vocal cords, allowing air passage through the rima glottidis.
  • Contraction of these muscles rotates the muscular processes medially and the vocal processes laterally, widening the glottis.
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes adductor muscles to dominate, potentially leading to airway obstruction and death.
  • Thus, they are termed the safety muscles of the larynx.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: Involved in adduction, pulling the vocal cords together.
  • C. Transverse cricoarytenoid: Adducts the vocal cords by pulling arytenoids together.
  • D. Oblique cricoarytenoid: Works with the transverse muscle to aid adduction.

Key Takeaway: The posterior cricoarytenoid (Option A) is the only abductor of the vocal cords, while other muscles like lateral, transverse, and oblique cricoarytenoids function in adduction.

choices.text: Bilateral external and internal laryngeal nerve
Bilateral internal and recurrent laryngeal nerve
Bilateral recurrent and external laryngeal nerve

questions.text: 50 years old male patient visited OPD with C/O horseness of voice. On examination there is a intact cough reflex. On layrngoscopy it was seen that vocal cords are in the cadaveric position. Which of the following nerve is liked to be damaged in the patient?
questions.solution:
• Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve: Causes anesthesia of the supraglottic mucosa and loss of cough reflex, leading to a higher risk of foreign bodies entering the larynx. However, this patient's cough reflex is intact, ruling out internal laryngeal nerve damage.
  • External laryngeal nerve damage: Affects the cricothyroid muscle, leading to weakness in tightening the vocal cords and phonation. Alone, it wouldn't lead to the cadaveric position but contributes when combined with recurrent nerve damage.
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve damage:
    • Unilateral: Results in the vocal cord being fixed in a paramedian position between abduction and adduction. The other vocal cord can compensate for phonation, making the condition less severe.
    • Bilateral: Both vocal cords lie in a paramedian position, causing loss of phonation and difficulty in breathing.
  • Damage to both recurrent and external laryngeal nerves: When both nerves are damaged bilaterally, it results in complete paralysis of all intrinsic muscles of the larynx, fixing the vocal cords in a cadaveric position (fully abducted and non-functional). This condition causes severe respiratory compromise and loss of voice, fitting the clinical scenario.

Why Not Others:

  • A and B: Internal laryngeal nerve damage would cause loss of the cough reflex, which is not observed in this case.
  • C: Bilateral recurrent nerve damage alone leads to a paramedian position, not the cadaveric position seen here.

Key Takeaway:

Cadaveric position of the vocal cords occurs with bilateral recurrent and external laryngeal nerve damage, leading to complete paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx and severe respiratory issues.

choices.text: Secretomotor to glands in the mucosa

questions.text: Which of the following is affected in case of injury to branch recurrent laryngeal nerve suppling to trachea?
questions.solution:
• Nerve supply of the trachea:
  • Parasympathetic fibers: Originate from the vagus nerve through the recurrent laryngeal nerve, responsible for:
    • Secretomotor function (Option A): Stimulates mucus glands in the tracheal mucosa.
    • Sensory innervation (Option C): Provides sensation to the mucous membrane of the trachea.
    • Motor innervation (Option D): Controls the trachealis muscle, aiding in adjusting the diameter of the trachea.
  • Sympathetic fibers: Derived from the middle cervical sympathetic ganglion, primarily responsible for vasomotor actions (Option B), regulating blood flow.

Why Not Others:

  • A: Injury would not affect secretomotor function as it is parasympathetic.
  • C: Sensory function remains intact as it is also parasympathetic.
  • D: Motor function to the trachealis muscle would also be intact because it's controlled by parasympathetic fibers.

Key Takeaway:

Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve affects vasomotor action, while other functions (secretomotor, sensory, and motor to trachealis muscle) remain due to their parasympathetic origin.
